sen.j: 初期の検地では統一した書式による検地帳が存在しなかった（例えば、村切の未確立の問題など）。
sen.e: At an early stage of kenchi, there was no standardized form of kenchi-cho, because there existed some policies yet to be implemented, such as "muragiri" (the formation of cultivated land done per village through kenchi during the early modern ages of Japan, which reorganized the complicated rights on land in medieval Japan).

sen.j: 豊臣政権（太閤検地）では文禄期以後、江戸幕府では寛文・延宝検地以後に統一した書式が定められた。
sen.e: Under the regime of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, it was only after the Bunroku era (A.D. 1592 - 1596) that the standardized form of kenchi-cho was established for "Taiko-kenchi" (the land survey by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI), and under Edo "bakufu" (Japanese feudal regime headed by a shogun), the standardized form was established only after the land survey in Kanbun (A.D. 1661 - 1673) and Enpo (A.D. 1673 - 1681) era was implemented.

sen.j: 封建領主側は検地帳に記された村の石高の集計（村高）を元にして年貢・諸役を賦課した（村請）。
sen.e: Based on "muradaka" (the total yield of a village) written on kenchi-cho, the feudal lord imposed "nengu" (land tax) and "shoyaku" (miscellaneous taxes other than nengu) on villagers as a whole, which was called "murauke" (the village-wide, collective responsibility for tax payment).

sen.j: 検地の実施後、その結果を元にしてそれぞれの村の石盛を決定し、村内の田畑・屋敷地について、一筆ごとに以下の項目を記載していく。
sen.e: Based on the result of kenchi, "kokumori" (the estimated yield from the land per "tan" [the old Japanese unit of land area]) was calculated in each village, and then, the following items were entered on kenchi-cho for each parcel of paddy, field, and residential area of the village.

sen.j: すなわち字名（所在地の地名）・地目（種類）・品位（上・中・下・下々からなる品質）・面積・分米（石高）・名請人である。
sen.e: The entries were "azana" (name of the location), "chimoku" (category of the land), rank of the land's fertility (high/middle/low/very-low), area of the land, "bunmai" (yield from the land), and "naukenin" (farmer certified as the owner of the paddy, the field, and the house, who was entitled and obliged to cultivate its land, and was responsible for nengu and shoyaku).
